This vignette is designed to guide you through the process of exploring various color palettes using `cartographr`. The goal is to apply different palettes to a map and observe the aesthetic variations they bring.

## Setup

Initially, we load the necessary libraries: `cartographr` for map-making, dplyr for data manipulation, and `ggplot2` for plotting. These libraries provide the functions and themes we need to create our maps and apply the palettes.

```{r setup}
library(cartographr)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
```

```{r set environment, include=FALSE}
set_output_size(c(160,160))
set_attribution(FALSE)
```

We set the output size for our maps and prepare to load OpenStreetMap (OSM) data for Hamburg, Germany.

```{r load osm, eval=F}
hamburg <- get_osmdata(lat = 53.545, lon = 10.000, x_distance = 1200)
```

Here, we create a data frame `df_pal` that contains a list of palette names. We then use a row-wise operation to apply each palette to our map data (osm) and store the resulting plot object. This allows us to see how each palette affects the mapâ€™s appearance.


```{r load all palettes, eval = F}
df_pal <- tibble (palettes= c("alphabet", "arctic","autumn", "bw",
                        "desert","evening", "gray", "iberia", "imhof","lines","midnight",
                        "minimal","metropolitan","swiss","tropical"),
                  hamburg = list(hamburg)) |>
  rowwise() |>
  mutate(p = list(hamburg |> plot_map(palettes) + theme_infomap() + labs(title = palettes)))
```

## Palette overview

Finally, we extract and display all the map plots from `df_pal`.

```{r plot palettes, echo = FALSE, eval=F, results='hide',fig.keep='all', fig.dpi=72, fig.dim=c(6,6), out.width="100%"}
df_pal |> pull(p)
```
